pullRequest.body:
Those simplifications were found by [`tryAtEachStep`](https://github.com/dwrensha/tryAtEachStep).

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

LGTM!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12957044209/job/36144602826)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12957044209/job/36144603110)
First of all: these are nice reductions in line length! I think one should look closely at these changes, however - if there is any new defeq abuse happening. Can you comment on this?
First of all: these are nice reductions in line length! I think one should look closely at these changes, however - if there is any new defeq abuse happening. Can you comment on this?

For example: this *looks* like this was using many API lemmas before, and the `rfl` omits them all. Is this change kosher?

A similar question applies to most other `rfl` changes.

[`SpectrumRestricts`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Quasispectrum.html#SpectrumRestricts) is just a type alias for `QuasispectrumRestricts`. Maybe this signals that having both at once just causes more confusion?
ok, this rfl seems like it is not a defqe abuse. Perhaps @j-loreaux can take a look if further refactors around `QuasispectrumRestricts` are a good idea, but likely in a separate pr.
The current proof was just a remnant from before I made it a type alias. They used to be different and this proof was required. The `rfl` here is a good change.
This changes seems fine; the tauto change also (assuming it benchmarks).
Ack
This could be fine; somebody more familiar with this file should check.
Not familiar with the file either but this does look fine to me. This seems to be a standard "casting behaves as expected" lemma, and those are usually just `subst_vars; rfl`.
perhaps @kmill can confirm that this change is fine?

Does this work?
```suggestion
  constructor <;> exact fun h i j hij ‚Ü¶ h j i hij.symm
```
works, and is even nicer...

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma getVert_copy {u v w x : V} (p : G.Walk u v) (i : ‚Ñï) (h : u = w) (h' : v = x) :
```
Can this be inlined into the previous `refine`?

it can like this:
```
    ¬∑ refine ciInf_le_of_le (bddBelow_projectiveSemiNormAux (0 : ‚®Ç[ùïú] i, E i)) ‚ü®0, lifts_zero‚ü©
        <| Preorder.le_refl (projectiveSeminormAux _)
```
I'm not sure it is an improvement. Wdyt, @vihdzp ?
Not as clean as I would've hoped, I think the proof can stay as is.

```suggestion
theorem Gamma_zero_bot : Gamma 0 = ‚ä• := rfl
```
